Description: This double snuffbox of chiselled gold is in the form of a stylised scallop shell with a plain base and straight sides. The sides are plain with reeded moulding. The lid, divided in the centre, has a chiselled decoration in low relief on a sanded ground. At top a ducal coronet is surmounted by curved vertical bans, arranged in paris, with designs of a trellis, birds under a baldachin, masks with festoons of drapery, busts of a woman (or a bearded man) in a medallion, all divided by swept lines terminating in acanthus foliage with heads of an eagle or a dragon. The exterior of the base is engraved with an elaborate heraldic achievement, a shield-of-arms. The coat-of-arms is that of James, first Duke of Chandos (1673-1744).

Exhibitions.ExhTitle: Objects of Vertu: Precious Works of the Eighteenth Century
Exhibitions.Textblock: Objects of Vertu: Precious Works of the Eighteenth Century. The Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. 1984.

Provenance: James Brydges, 9th Baron Chandos, 1st Earl of Carnarvon, 1st Duke of Chandos (1674-1744), England, by commission;  Henry Brydges, 2nd Duke of Chandos (1708-1771), England, by inheritance;  James Brydges, 3rd Duke of Chandos (1731-1789), England, by inheritance; Richard Temple-Nugent-Brydges-Chandos-Grenville, 1st Duke of Buckingham and Chandos, 5th Viscount Cobham (1776-1839), England, by inheritance;  Richard Plantagenet Temple-Nugent-Brydges-Chandos-Grenville, 2nd Duke of Buckingham and Chandos, 6th Viscount Cobham (1797-1861), England, by inheritance;  Richard Plantagenet Campbell Temple-Nugent-Brydges-Chandos-Grenville, 3rd Duke of Buckingham and Chandos, 7th Viscount Cobham (1823-1889), England, by inheritance;  Mary Temple-Gore-Langton, Baroness Kinloss (1852-1944), Stowe, England, by inheritance;  Sale, Christie's, London, June 2, 1905, no. 40;  Harding; Paris;  Henry Walters, Baltimore, 1914, by purchase;  Walters Art Museum, 1931, by bequest.
Title: Double Snuffbox with the Coat of Arms of James, first Duke of Chandos
